title-group.article-title: A Cardinal Function Method of Solution of the Equation $\Delta u = u - u^3$

abstract.p: The steady-state form of the Klein-Gordon equation is given by \begin{equation*} \tag{\ast} \Delta u = u - u^3,\quad u = u(X),\quad X \in R^3 \end{equation*}. For solutions which are spherically symmetric, $(^\ast)$ takes the form $\ddot{u} + 2\dot{u}/r = u - u^3, u = u(r)$, where $r$ is the distance from the origin in $R^3$. The function $y = ru$ satisfies \begin{equation*}\tag{\ast\ast\} \ddot{y} = y - y^3/r^2 \end{equation*}. It is known that $(^{\ast\ast})$ has solutions $\{y_n\}^\infty_{n=0}$, where $y_n$ has exactly $n$ zeros in $(0, \infty)$, and where $y(0) = y(\infty) = 0$. In this paper, an approximation is obtained for the solution $y_0$ by minimizing a certain functional over a class of functions of the form $$\sum_{k=-m}^m a_k \operatorname{sinc} \bigg\lbrack \frac{r - kh_m}{h_m} \bigg\rbrack.$$ It is shown that the norm of the error is $O(m^{3/8} \exp(-\alpha m^{1/2}))$ as $m \rightarrow \infty$, where $\alpha$ is positive.
